Ozone-enhanced deep catalytic oxidation of toluene over a platinum-ceria-supported BEA zeolite catalyst Hailin Xiao a Junliang Wu a b ⁎ Xueqing Wang a Jialing Wang a Shengpeng Mo a Mingli Fu a b Limin Chen a b Daiqi Ye a b ⁎ a School of Environment and Energy, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou 510006, China School of Environment and Energy South China University of Technology Guangzhou 510006 China b National Engineering Laboratory for VOCs Pollution Control Technology and Equipment, Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Environment and Pollution Control, Guangzhou 510006, China National Engineering Laboratory for VOCs Pollution Control Technology and Equipment Guangdong Provincial Key Laboratory of Atmospheric Environment and Pollution Control Guangzhou 510006 China ⁎ Corresponding authors at: School of Environment and Energy, South China University of Technology, Guangzhou 510006, China. School of Environment and Energy South China University of Technology Guangzhou 510006 China Graphical abstract Deep catalytic oxidation of toluene in low concentrations by ozone on a supported Pt-Ce/BEA catalyst using a facile preparation method was investigated. The catalyst was prepared using a simple grinding and calcination process, and then characterized by inductively coupled plasma elemental analysis, X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy, H2 temperature programmed reduction, O2 and toluene temperature programmed desorption, and ultraviolet Raman spectroscopy. The characterization results showed that Pt nanoparticles and CeO2 intimately contacted on the surface of the catalyst, and a strong interaction occurred between them. The catalyst was employed for toluene oxidation with ozone because a strong interaction occurs between the Pt NPs and CeO2. We aimed to investigate the interaction between the Pt NPs and CeO2; thus, we compared the three catalysts. Pt-Ce/BEA exhibited superior catalytic performance (>99% toluene conversion and >99% CO2 selectivity at 90 °C) compared to Pt/BEA (85% toluene conversion and 63% CO2 selectivity) and Ce/BEA (>99% toluene conversion and 59% CO2 selectivity). The strong interaction between the Pt nanoparticles and CeO2 increased the amount of oxygen vacancy and thus improved the ozone decomposition activity, which yielded more active oxygen species and contributed to the toluene oxidation. Keywords Pt-Ce Ozone Catalytic oxidation Interaction Oxygen vacancy 1 Introduction In recent years, there has been increasing concern regarding the abatement of volatile organic compounds (VOCs) at low concentration levels in industry and indoor circumstances because of health and air quality issues. Today, adsorption, combustion, and catalytic combustion are widely used. However, adsorption needs frequent regeneration, and combustion and catalytic combustion operate at high temperature rendering them uneconomic for directly treating VOCs at low concentrations. Hence, a novel energy-saving technique is anticipated. The ozone-catalytic oxidation (OZCO) method is a promising approach for VOC degradation at relatively low concentrations under mild conditions [1–3]. It has been reported that the required temperature for VOC oxidation is much lower than that of combustion and catalytic combustion, which is of significant practical interest [4,5]. Soltan et al. [6] prepared a supported MnOx/γ-Al2O3 catalyst for the OZCO of toluene. The experimental results showed that toluene could be stably degraded at 90 °C with 95% conversion. Zaitan et al. [7] investigated a high silica zeolite ZSM-5 for the adsorption of toluene, which was then regenerated by ozone at room temperature when ZSM-5 achieved saturation. After four successive cycles of adsorption and regeneration, the adsorption efficiency could maintain a level of 92–99%. Einaga et al. [8] reported that a supported Mn/SiO2 catalyst obtained 80% benzene conversion with ozone at 70 °C. Huang et al. [9] tested a series of metal oxides (Mn, Co, Ni, Cu, Zn, and Ce) supported on a ZSM-5 zeolite for OZCO of benzene, and reported that the MnO2/ZSM-5 catalyst showed the best activity and benzene could be completely converted at room temperature. Though currently OZCO is recognized as an effective method for low-temperature oxidation of VOCs, some challenges remain for the application of this method. Among the main drawbacks is that the VOCs cannot be completely mineralized to harmless products (CO2 and H2O), which means that a certain number of by-products are generated and emitted [10,11]. Soltan et al. [6] found that a supported MnOx/γ-alumina catalyst achieved 62% CO2 selectivity at 90 °C during the OZCO process. Teramoto et al. [12] reported that a Zr0.77Ce0.23O2SiO2 catalyst showed 80% CO2 selectivity at 100 °C during OZCO, accompanying the formation of formic acid. Moussavi et al. [13] used an MgO-supported granular activated carbon composite as a catalyst to remove toluene in the presence of ozone and reported that the major by-products were formic acid, benzaldehyde, and so on. The by-products accumulating on the catalyst surface led to the catalyst deactivation and shortened the catalyst lifetime. Moreover, the release of residual ozone should be a concern, which is among the major pollutants near ground level. Therefore, it is of great importance to develop novel catalysts to simultaneously achieve complete oxidation of VOCs and ozone decomposition. Recently, researchers have claimed that the two-component catalysts exhibited synergistic effects for catalytic oxidation of VOCs by ozone. Einaga et al. [14] compared the catalytic properties of MnOx combined with Cu, Ni, and Fe and concluded that Cu-Mn/SiO2 catalysts showed higher steady-state activity than Mn/SiO2 catalysts for benzene oxidation. Zhu et al. [15,16] reported that the performance of OZCO was enhanced by a combination of Ag and Mn on HZSM-5 for benzene oxidation compared to that with the use of Ag/HZSM-5 and Mn/HZSM-5, and the promotion was related to excellent ozone decomposition performance using the Ag-Mn two-component catalyst. Rezaei et al. [17] added Pt to an MnOx/γ-Al2O3 catalyst and found that the superior activity of Pt-MnOx/γ-Al2O3 might have been because of the interaction between Pt and Mn, which was favorable for ozone decomposition and consequently toluene oxidation. The aforementioned results provide a hint that suitable two-component catalysts might achieve better catalytic performance than a single-component catalyst. Ceria is often used as a good promoter for its active oxygen species storage capacity. Noble metal catalysts, such as Pt, show a good ability to complete oxidation of VOCs by ozone [18]. The catalyst containing Pt and CeO2 has been widely studied in thermal catalytic oxidation of VOCs [19–21] and has exhibited a synergistic effect between Pt and CeO2. For example, Escribano et al. [20] used the supported Pt and Pt-Ce catalysts for the catalytic oxidation of toluene and found that the Pt-Ce catalyst had high catalytic activity which might have been related to the presence of the Pt-CeO2 interface. Consequently, the catalyst containing Pt and Ce species appears to be a potential candidate for OZCO. However, prior to this study, this catalyst had not been explored in the catalytic oxidation of VOCs by ozone. Toluene, among the typical VOCs, is widely used in the petrochemical, pharmaceutical, dyeing, fine chemistry, polymer industries and occurs in indoor circumstances. In this work, toluene was chosen as a model compound for the catalytic oxidation of the Pt-Ce two-component catalyst assisted by ozone. The Pt-Ce/BEA catalyst and the catalysts containing Pt or CeO2 were prepared using a grinding and calcination process. To determine the interaction between the Pt nanoparticles (NPs) and Ce species on the surface of the catalyst, the catalysts were characterized by inductively coupled plasma (ICP) elemental analysis, X-ray diffraction (XRD), transmission electron microscopy (TEM), H2 temperature programmed reduction (H2-TPR), O2 and toluene temperature programmed desorption (O2-TPD and toluene-TPD), and ultraviolet (UV) Raman spectroscopy. The performance of the catalysts for catalytic oxidation of toluene was investigated in detail. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation BEA zeolites were dealuminized by an aqueous HNO3 (Aladdin, 65–68%) solution with commercial BEA zeolites (Zeolyst, Si/Al = 25). Pt/BEA (Pt, 1 wt%), Ce/BEA (Si/Ce = 100:1), and Pt-Ce/BEA (Pt, 1 wt% and Si/Ce = 100:1) catalysts were obtained via grinding the support with chloroplatinic acid (Aladdin, 8 wt% in H2O) solution and a cerium nitrate (Aladdin, 99.95%) solid. The optimized cerium nitrate solid, or chloroplatinic acid solution, or both were mixed with the pretreated BEA, and then hand ground for 10 min in an agate mortar. The mixture was dried at 100 °C for 2 h and then calcined at 550 °C for 12 h in air. All the calcined catalysts were compressed, crushed, and sieved through 40–60 mesh sieves prior to activity evaluation. 2.2 Catalyst characterization The loading of metal was measured using ICP analysis (4300 DV, Perkin Elmer). TEM measurements were conducted using a Hitachi H-7650 at an acceleration voltage of 120 kV. The crystal structure of the samples was analyzed using XRD on an advance D8 (Bruker) equipped with Cu-Kα radiation at an acceleration voltage and current of 40 kV and 40 mA, respectively, and within the 2θ range 5–85° at 1° min−1 with a step size of 0.05°. Raman spectra were obtained using a LabRAM HR Evolution Laser Raman Spectrometer (Jobin Yvon Horiba) with a charge coupled device. The UV Raman used a UV laser (λ = 325 nm) with an output laser power of 5 mW and the wave number region was from 300 to 800 cm−1. The spectra were collected with gratings of 2400 grooves mm−1 and recorded by two times of 60 s subsequent laser exposer. H2-TPR profiles were recorded using a chemisorption analyzer (Micromeritics Chemisorb 2920II). A total of 100 mg of samples was first treated under Ar flow (30 mL min−1) at 300 °C for 30 min, followed by cooling to room temperature. Afterward, a flow of 10% H2/Ar (30 mL min−1) was switched into the tube and the samples were heated to 800 °C at a temperature ramp of 10 °C min−1. O2-TPD was conducted using a chemisorption analyzer (Micromeritics Chemisorb 2920II). A total of 100 mg of catalyst was pre-treated in He at 300 °C for 1 h and then cooled to 60 °C prior to the adsorption of the 5% O2/He mixture gas for 1 h. Afterward, the catalyst was heated to 110 °C and purged with He for 1 h to remove the surface water and physically adsorbed oxygen. Finally, the catalyst was treated with He and heated from 40 to 800 °C at a rate of 10 °C min−1, and the release of O2 was monitored using a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). 2.3 Temperature programmed desorption of toluene (toluene-TPD) Toluene-TPD was analyzed using a continuous sampling gas analysis system (HPR20, Hiden). A total of 20 mg of samples was pre-treated in N2 flow (50 mL min−1) at 200 °C for 0.5 h and then cooled to 50 °C prior to the adsorption of toluene. After saturation with toluene, the samples were flushed with N2 flow (50 mL min−1) until a flat baseline of MS was obtained. The profiles of toluene-TPD were recorded online at a heating rate of 5 °C min−1 up to 500 °C. 2.4 Activity evaluation A schematic diagram of the experimental setup is shown in Fig. 1 . OZCO or thermal catalysis of toluene was performed in a fixed bed flow-through quartz tube reactor (i.d. 6 mm) using 0.1 g of catalyst with a size of 40–60 mesh at different temperatures and dry air. All catalysts used in each experiment were fresh. Reaction gases for the catalytic reaction were prepared by mixing toluene in N2 (>99.9995% purity) and O2 (>99.9995% purity) in cylinders. Ozone was produced from pure O2 using a dielectric barrier discharge (DBD) reactor. Prior to OZCO (with ozone) or thermal catalysis (without ozone), 0.1 g of catalyst was heated at 120 °C in N2 flow for 30 min to remove the water in the catalyst, and then cooled to room temperature. The air stream containing toluene passed through the catalyst. Following the saturated adsorption of toluene, the DBD reactor was turned on and ozone was introduced to the catalyst (in the case of thermal catalysis, however, no ozone was introduced). The reaction began, and the reaction temperature was controlled using a heating apparatus. The influence of adsorption could be excluded in the actual calculation of toluene conversion. The inlet concentrations of toluene and ozone were 22 ppm and 300 ppm, respectively, and the gas flow rate was 100 ml min−1 (N2: 80 mL min−1, O3 and O2: 20 mL min−1) corresponding to a weight hourly specific velocity (WHSV) of 60,000 mL h−1 g−1. The concentrations of toluene, CO, and CO2 were measured using a gas chromatography (GC-9560, Shang hai Fanwei instrument & equipment Co.) equipped with two flame-ionization detectors (FIDs). One FID was used for toluene analysis, and the other methanizer-FID was used to determine the concentrations of CO and CO2. The GC was calibrated for concentration using a standard gas. The ozone concentration at the outlet was monitored using an ozone analyzer (106, 2B Technology). The toluene adsorption and ozone decomposition experiments without toluene were performed using the aforementioned experimental equipment. Before the mixed gas containing toluene (22 ppm) or ozone (300 ppm) passed through the catalyst bed, 0.1 g of catalyst was heated at 120 °C in N2 flow for 30 min to remove the water, and then cooled to room temperature in the same air stream. As soon as the gas flow passed through the catalyst, the outlet concentration of the toluene or ozone was detected online via the GC or the ozone analyzer. The definitions of ozone conversion, toluene conversion, carbon balance, and CO2 selectivity are as follows, respectively: Ozone conversion % = C O 3 in - C O 3 out C O 3 in × 100 % Toluene conversion % = C toluene in - C toluene out C toluene in × 100 % Carbon balance % = C CO out + C C O 2 out 7 × C toluene in - C toluene out × 100 % C O 2 selectivity % = C C O 2 out 7 × C toluene in - C toluene out × 100 % 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization The result of the metal content characterized using ICP is summarized in Table 1 . The metal content was near the calculated value. The Pt/BEA and Pt-Ce/BEA catalysts had similar Pt loading, and the Ce/BEA and Pt-Ce/BEA catalysts had similar Ce loading. XRD patterns of the catalysts are depicted in Fig. 2 . The diffraction peak of the support was in accordance with the typical BEA zeolite structure [22,23]. Two intense peaks at 8.1° and 22.8° were found in all samples, indicating that the crystal structure of the zeolite was the same after loading with Pt and Ce species. As for Ce/BEA and Pt-Ce/BEA, no diffraction peak assigned to the Ce species was detected. It was suggested that the Ce species was highly dispersed in the BEA. Except for the peaks originating from the BEA substrate, the peaks associated with the diffractions of Pt (1 1 1) at 39.8°, Pt (2 0 0) at 46.3° and Pt (2 2 0) at 67.6° (JCPDS No. 65-2868) were detected in Pt/BEA and Pt-Ce/BEA. This implied that Pt was likely in a metallic state in these two catalysts. It was also found that the Pt diffraction peaks of Pt-Ce/BEA were sharper and higher compared to those of Pt/BEA, indicating that the Pt particles increased in size when coexisting with the Ce species. In the partially enlarged details, it was observed that the Pt (2 2 0) peak at 67.6° of the Pt-Ce/BEA catalyst slightly shifted to a lower angle compared to that of the Pt/BEA catalyst, which signified the expansion of the Pt (2 2 0) lattice. During the process of calcination, the presence of Ce species might have influenced the Pt lattice and resulted in lattice distortion of Pt [24,25]. Presumably, Pt strongly interacted with Ce species on Pt-Ce/BEA. Fig. 3 shows the TEM images of the catalysts. They were nearly the same in both the BEA (Fig. 3a) and the Ce/BEA (Fig. 3b), which displayed the particle morphology of the support. The high-resolution TEM images (Fig. 3c) of Ce/BEA showed that the spacing of the lattice fringes of the Ce species was 0.311 nm, corresponding to the (1 1 1) planes of CeO2 and indicating that Ce species occurred as CeO2. Fig. S1 provides more TEM images demonstrating the presence of independent regions of CeO2 lattice fringes on the surface of the BEA. These images also show that the diameter of the separated CeO2 was 2–5 nm, and CeO2 was highly dispersed on the BEA surface. This phenomenon was in accordance with the results of XRD. As shown in Fig. 3d (the Pt/BEA catalysts) and Fig. 3f (the Pt-Ce/BEA catalysts), the Pt NPs were found to uniformly distribute over the surface of the catalysts. The Pt (1 1 1) atomic planes with a lattice spacing of 0.23 nm were obviously observed as shown in Fig. 3e. Notably, as shown in Fig. 3g, the Pt NPs and the CeO2 were closely in contact instead of separately presented on the surface. More TEM images are shown in Fig. S2. It was suggested that the Pt NPs might selectively grow adjacent to CeO2. A strong interaction between Pt NPs and CeO2 can form active sites for a catalytic reaction, and thus enhance the catalytic activity [26,27]. In this work, excellent performance of the Pt-Ce/BEA catalyst in toluene removal using the OZCO method was expected. To further understand the interaction between the Pt NPs and CeO2, H2-TPR patterns (Fig. 4 ) of Pt-Ce/BEA, Pt/BEA, Ce/BEA, and BEA were determined. It could be seen that the BEA showed no distinct reduction peak in the tested temperature range. For the supported CeO2 catalyst, the reduction of CeO2 species could be generally divided into three temperature ranges: 250–400 °C, 400–600 °C, and 600–1000 °C, which represented the reduction of oxygen on the surface, subsurface, and in bulk, respectively [28,29]. In the case of Ce/BEA, the TPR profiles showed two reduction peaks at 300 °C and 737 °C, respectively, indicating a reduction of the surface and bulk oxygen in the Ce/BEA. A small amount of PtOx formed in Pt/BEA and Pt-Ce/BEA during the calcination process. Only one reduction peak appeared at 280 °C for Pt/BEA, which could be attributed to a reduction of Pt2+ because of the strong interaction with the BEA zeolite [30]. After incorporating the Pt and Ce species on the support, the H2-TPR profile obviously changed. Two reduction peaks were attributed to the reduction of Pt2+ and the surface oxygen of CeO2 overlapped and formed a broad peak, centered at 305 °C. Compared to the profile of Pt/BEA, the reduction peak of Pt2+ shifted from 280 °C to 305 °C, indicating that the Pt2+ strengthened interacting with the support which might have been because of the presence of CeO2. Compared to the profile of Ce/BEA, the peak position of the surface oxygen reduction of CeO2 was nearly the same. The peaks at 445 °C and 516 °C were ascribed to a reduction in subsurface oxygen. No bulk oxygen peaks could be found, suggesting that the reduction peak of the CeO2 species shifted to the lower temperature because of the introduction of Pt which facilitated the spillover of oxygen from CeO2 to the adjacent Pt [31]. Libuda et al. [31] reported that the oxygen spillover from CeO2 to Pt only occurs on the CeO2 in direct contact with Pt. Therefore, the results of the H2-TPR provided additional evidence of the interaction between the Pt NPs and CeO2. Some research studies regarding Pt and CeO2 have included the investigation of oxygen vacancy [27,32] derived from the interaction between Pt and CeO2. UV Raman is sensitive to surface defect sites in CeO2 and was conducted to investigate the oxygen vacancy in catalysts. The results are shown in Fig. 5 a. Two obvious peaks are observed for Pt/BEA and Pt-Ce/BEA; the peak near 460 cm−1 was attributed to the symmetric stretching vibrations mode (F2g) in the cubic fluorite ceria and the broad peak near 600 cm−1 was assigned to be the band of the defect-induced (D) mode connected with the oxygen vacancy induced by the existence of Ce3+ [33,34]. It has been reported that the ratio of peak areas of the bands at 600 cm−1 and 460 cm−1 (A600/A460) can be applied as an index to evaluate the density of the oxygen vacancy [35–37]. It can be seen from Table 2 that the A600/A460 molar ratio of Pt-Ce/BEA (1.85) is larger than that of Ce/BEA (0.67). Thus, the Pt-Ce/BEA catalyst had more oxygen vacancies. The presence of Pt NPs could have enhanced the formation of surface oxygen vacancy in the CeO2. A similar phenomenon has been previously reported in the literature [32,38]. The oxygen vacancy of the catalyst has been claimed to influence the adsorbed oxygen species. Thus, O2-TPD was conducted to investigate the oxygen species in the catalysts. The results are shown in Fig. 5b. Accordingly, the desorption peak of O2-TPD could be divided into two regions [39]. The peak emerged at a temperature below 350 °C corresponded to the oxygen adsorbed on the catalyst surface oxygen vacancy (denoted as Oa) [37]. The peak above 350 °C was distinguished as the desorption of the catalyst lattice oxygen (denoted as Ol). It has been reported that a higher Oa ratio (Oa/(Oa + Ol)) always is accompanied by more oxygen vacancies [40,41]. In other words, the Oa ratio reflects the concentration of the surface oxygen vacancy. The concentration of the surface oxygen vacancy was calculated and is shown in Table 2. It was obvious that Pt-Ce/BEA had the higher concentration of oxygen vacancy in accordance with the Raman results. 3.2 Adsorption and catalytic activity evaluation 3.2.1 Adsorption The toluene adsorption performance of catalysts was tested, and the results are shown in Fig. 6 a. The breakthrough time of the samples decreased in the following order: Pt-Ce/BEA (505 min) > Ce/BEA (468 min) > BEA (415 min) > Pt/BEA (310 min). It could be deduced that introducing Ce could increase the adsorption capacity, but introducing Pt reduced the adsorption capacity. After simultaneously introducing Pt and Ce into BEA, the longest breakthrough time was achieved. Fig. 6b shows the toluene-TPD profiles of the catalysts. The desorption temperature of the samples was in the following order: Pt-Ce/BEA (126 °C) ≈ Pt/BEA (125 °C) ≈ BEA (124 °C) > Ce/BEA (113 °C). The desorption temperature of BEA was nearly the same as that of Pt-Ce/BEA and Pt/BEA. The loading of Pt did not improve the adsorption of toluene. It could be speculated that the most adsorption of toluene occurred on BEA, not on Pt or CeO2. The higher desorption temperature meant there was a stronger interaction between the toluene and adsorption sites, which has a favorable effect on the activation and oxidation of toluene [42]. Ce/BEA showed the lowest desorption temperature indicating that the loading of CeO2 alone could weaken the interaction between the toluene and adsorption sites. 3.2.2 Ozone decomposition The ozone decomposition performance was evaluated at different temperatures from 30 °C to 110 °C. As shown in Fig. 7 , ozone decomposition performance of the Pt-Ce/BEA, Ce/BEA, and Pt/BEA catalysts increased with temperature. At a lower temperature range (<70 °C), the ozone decomposition of Ce/BEA and Pt/BEA was similar. However, when the temperature was above 70 °C, the ozone decomposition of Ce/BEA significantly increased and was much higher than that of the Pt/BEA at 90 °C and 110 °C. Within the temperature range of 30–110 °C, Pt-Ce/BEA showed the highest ozone decomposition. It completely decomposed ozone above 70 °C. Considering ozone decomposition on the catalyst surface is an important initiation step for OZCO, the catalyst with an excellent property for ozone decomposition has potential good performance for toluene oxidation by ozone. The increasing ozone decomposition rate with temperature was greater for Ce/BEA compared to that of Pt/BEA. The difference in this rate between Pt/BEA and Ce/BEA showed that they each had different active sites for ozone decomposition. The active site of Pt/BEA for ozone decomposition should be Pt according to previous studies [18,43]. Regarding Ce/BEA, Zhang et al. [44] and Zhu et al. [45] proposed a surface oxygen vacancy was the active site for ozone decomposition in transitional metal oxides. According to the results of UV Raman and O2-TPD the oxygen vacancy existed in Ce/BEA. It could be conjectured that the active site for ozone decomposition of Ce/BEA was an oxygen vacancy. Pt-Ce/BEA had both Pt and more oxygen vacancies, and thus exhibited the highest ozone decomposition performance. 3.2.3 Catalytic properties Before investigating the catalytic oxidation of toluene by ozone, the removal of toluene by ozone alone and catalysts alone should be excluded. According to previous works [46,47], the direct degradation of toluene by O3 alone can be ignored at low temperature. In this work, toluene was barely directly converted by O3 (Fig. S3). In addition, as shown in Fig. 8 , toluene degradation by a catalyst without ozone was less than 10% at a temperature lower than 110 °C. Ce/BEA showed nearly no catalytic effect on toluene oxidation within the range 30–200 °C. The temperatures in which there was 90% conversion of toluene (T90) for Pt/BEA and Pt-Ce/BEA were 130 and 165 °C, respectively. The activity of Pt/BEA was higher than that of Pt-Ce/BEA during the thermal catalyst reaction. In the case of thermal catalysis, both Pt particle size and oxygen vacancy have an effect on a catalyst’s performance. According to our previous research [27], the index of the catalyst’s activity, the turnover frequency of Pt particles (TOFPt), was 10−3 s−1, much higher than that (TOFOV) of the oxygen vacancy (approximately 10−4 s−1), which meant that Pt played a much more significant role in toluene oxidation than did the oxygen vacancies. Generally, the smaller particle size of Pt in the catalysts containing Pt meant higher activity during thermal catalytic oxidation of VOCs. From the results of XRD, it was found that the particle size of Pt in Pt-Ce/BEA was larger than that of Pt/BEA, which resulted in decreasing catalytic performance. Hence, the removal of toluene at a low temperature by ozone alone and catalysts alone can be excluded. The performance of catalysts for toluene oxidation by ozone at various temperatures is shown in Fig. 9 . With increasing reaction temperature, the toluene conversion, carbon balance, CO2 selectivity, and ozone conversion of all the catalysts simultaneously increased. Compared to thermal catalysis, the performance of all the catalysts during OZCO significantly improved. For example, the toluene conversion was 95%, 85%, and 58% for Pt-Ce/BEA, Ce/BEA, and Pt/BEA, respectively, even at 30 °C. It increased to greater than 99%, greater than 99%, and 75% at 70 °C. Obviously, there was a synergistic effect between the ozone and catalyst during toluene oxidation, resulting in a change in the order of the performance of the catalysts during OZCO in contrast to thermal catalysis. This meant that there is a different reaction mechanism during OZCO and thermal catalysis. Comparing the ozone consumption in the absence and presence of toluene as shown in Figs. 7 and 9d, it was found that the ozone decomposition increased in the presence of toluene, i.e. ozone participated in the oxidation of toluene. Considering the slow reaction rate between ozone and toluene in air, the active oxygen species produced from ozone decomposition by the catalysts accounted for the oxidation of toluene [2,48,49]. O3 first catalytically decomposed into active oxygen species (O*) on the surface of the catalyst, and then further reacted with adsorbed toluene which was continuously oxidized into intermediate products and finally to CO2 [50,51]. The proposed mechanism is as follows: (R1) O 3 + S 1 → O 2 + O * (R2) O 3 + O * → O 2 + O 2 * (R3) O 2 * → O 2 + S 1 (R4) C 7 H 8 + S 2 → S 2 C 7 H 8 (R5) S 2 C 7 H 8 + O * → byproduct compounds + C O 2 Where S1 represents the catalytic active site of ozone decomposition, O * and O2 * represent absorbed active oxygen species on the catalyst surface, S2 represents the active sites of toluene, and S 2 C 7 H 8 represents the toluene adsorbed and activated in the S2. As shown in Fig. 7, it can be inferred that the active site (S1) for ozone decomposition was Pt or CeO2 (oxygen vacancy), not the BEA support (it showed very low performance for ozone decomposition). Meanwhile, because the desorption temperature of toluene on the samples (Pt-Ce/BEA, Pt/BEA, BEA) was nearly the same except for Ce/BEA (Ce species may change the textural properties of BEA), the active site (S2) for toluene adsorption was assumed to occur on the BEA support. Hui et al. [52] used MnO2/graphene to catalytically oxidize toluene by ozone and promoted a similar dual-site hypothesis. The different metal components played different roles in OZCO. Comparing Ce/BEA and Pt/BEA, Ce/BEA showed better toluene conversion (Fig. 9a) but Pt/BEA had a higher carbon balance (Fig. 9b). Hence, Ce seemed to tend to convert or decompose toluene to other products except COx and Pt tended to oxidize toluene to COx. When combining Pt and CeO2, Pt-Ce/BEA was observed to achieve outstanding performance in toluene conversion, carbon balance, CO2 selectivity, and ozone conversion. The temperature in which 99% of the toluene was converted decreased from 180 °C (thermal catalysis) to 70 °C. In addition, it could fully convert toluene to CO2 at 90 °C, with no detectable by-products; however, the CO2 selectivity of the Ce/BEA and Pt/BEA catalysts was merely 59% and 63% (Fig. 9c), respectively. Ozone conversion was also >99% above 90 °C. No residual ozone was emitted in the outlet flow using the Pt-Ce/BEA catalyst, which has practical significance in future applications. The excellent performance of Pt-Ce/BEA could be attributed to the interaction between Pt NPs and CeO2. As reported in the literature, the supported metal nanoparticles (such as Au, Ag, and Ru) would facilitate the formation of oxygen vacancies in CeO2 [53–55] because of the interaction between the metal and CeO2. In this work, Pt NPs and CeO2 intimately contacted on the support (see Fig. 3g). The interaction of Pt and CeO2 gave rise to electron migration from Pt to CeO2 (as reported by Libuda et al. [31]), leading to the transformation of Ce4+ to Ce3+ and an increase in the ratio of Ce3+/(Ce3+ + Ce4+), which can act as an index to quantify the number of oxygen vacancies [35,56,57]. The introduction of Pt decreased the energy required for the formation of an oxygen vacancy [58] and stimulated the formation of more oxygen vacancies in CeO2 [32,38,59]. Rezaei et al. [17] reported similar results in the case of a Pt-MnOx catalyst. Therefore, Pt-Ce/BEA had more oxygen vacancies than did Ce/BEA (see Fig. 5), resulting better ozone decomposition performance, and thus better toluene oxidation performance compared to Ce/BEA. In this work, the ratio of the amount of decomposed ozone to that of toluene was 13.6. This value is less than 18, which is for complete oxidation of toluene in theory if only oxygen atoms produced by ozone decomposition were involved in the oxidation of toluene. This meant that not only active oxygen atoms (O*) produced by ozone decomposition, but also oxygen molecules produced by ozone decomposition could participate in the oxidation of VOCs [60–62]. For example, in a similar study, Einaga and Futamura [63] found that the ratio of O3 to benzene ratio was approximately 10 (CO2 was the main products), which is less than 15, the value estimated from the stoichiometric equation. They proposed that oxygen molecules originating from ozone decomposition were involved in some auto-oxidation reactions to oxidize organic intermediates to final products. In a future work, it is important to optimize the ratio of ozone to toluene. 3.3 Stability of the Pt-Ce/BEA catalyst Catalyst stability is crucial to practical applications. As shown in Fig. 10 , the toluene conversion remained at 99% after 40 h of reaction time. No significant catalyst deactivation was observed. This suggested that the toluene could be thoroughly degraded, and fewer by-products formed and accumulated. No ozone was detected in the outlet during the whole test process. These results showed that the Pt-Ce/BEA demonstrated superior catalytic stability toward toluene oxidation by ozone. 4 Conclusions Complete catalytic oxidation of gas-phase toluene by ozone over the Pt-Ce/BEA, Pt/BEA, and Ce/BEA catalysts was investigated. The characterization results showed Pt NPs and CeO2 intimately contacted on the BEA support and an evidently strong interaction occurred which facilitated the formation of oxygen vacancies. The amount of oxygen vacancy contributed to the performance of the catalysts in ozone decomposition. Pt-Ce/BEA exhibited excellent ozone decomposition performance and generated more active oxygen species. The active oxygen species reacted with toluene and led to toluene oxidation. Pt-Ce/BEA can completely convert toluene to CO2 above 90 °C without residual O3 emitted and also showed good stability. coredata.dc:description: Deep catalytic oxidation of toluene in low concentrations by ozone on a supported Pt-Ce/BEA catalyst using a facile preparation method was investigated. The catalyst was prepared using a simple grinding and calcination process, and then characterized by inductively coupled plasma elemental analysis, X-ray diffraction, transmission electron microscopy, H2 temperature programmed reduction, O2 and toluene temperature programmed desorption, and ultraviolet Raman spectroscopy. The characterization results showed that Pt nanoparticles and CeO2 intimately contacted on the surface of the catalyst, and a strong interaction occurred between them. The catalyst was employed for toluene oxidation with ozone because a strong interaction occurs between the Pt NPs and CeO2. We aimed to investigate the interaction between the Pt NPs and CeO2; thus, we compared the three catalysts. Pt-Ce/BEA exhibited superior catalytic performance (>99% toluene conversion and >99% CO2 selectivity at 90 °C) compared to Pt/BEA (85% toluene conversion and 63% CO2 selectivity) and Ce/BEA (>99% toluene conversion and 59% CO2 selectivity). The strong interaction between the Pt nanoparticles and CeO2 increased the amount of oxygen vacancy and thus improved the ozone decomposition activity, which yielded more active oxygen species and contributed to the toluene oxidation.
coredata.dc:title: Ozone-enhanced deep catalytic oxidation of toluene over a platinum-ceria-supported BEA zeolite catalyst
